fields.description:
For user facing services it is necessary to make a distinction between what users see as the component IP (ie what dns responses and eucarc contain) and what the components are using to communicate with each other.

Attached is a topology that requires --bind-addr to be add to all Java components in order for components to go to enabled, but when that is in place all URLs presented to users are those of the internal addresses.
fields.summary: Need a way to distinguish between user facing and component facing interfaces

comments.body:
There is a related comment from [~decker] on EUCA-9117, but on further discussion something like the below is likely preferable.

The IP used to register components should be the internal IP and there should be a cloud property (or properties) that define the interfaces that web services should listen on (this configuration is already possible for DNS). The web services framework would listen on the "--bind-addr" for internal use (on port 8773) and later in the bootstrap process when cloud properties are available a public listener would be started on an IP matching the public interface (cidr?)

Host.getHostAddresses (or similar) could be used to map registered services from their internal IP (Host.getBindAddress) to the appropriate public IP and this would be used with both external DNS requests (split horizon) and eucarc service URLs.

JGroups would not need to be updated and DNS already supports configuration of the interface(s) to listen on. One item to verify with DNS is that UDP responses are from the expected IP.

I propose the following to address this issue.

h4. Configurable port and bind addresses for DNS and Web Services 
DNS and Web Services will initially start up listeners on the bind address (--bind-addr) and default ports (53, 8773) only. When  configuration from the database is available later in the start up process listeners will be started on the configured addresses and ports in addition to the initial listeners.

The default configuration will be for the web services listener to listen on all addresses (0.0.0.0) on port 8773 and DNS on the detected or configured bind address on port 53.

e.g.
{code}
  dns.dns_listener_address_match = 10.111.0.0/16
  bootstrap.webservices.listener_address_match = 10.111.0.0/16
{code}

h4. DNS host mappings
The DNS service will be updated to support mapping of registered host addresses to addresses on alternative host interfaces by CIDR. A cloud property would allow a  list of mappings to be defined, each mapping would consist of:

{code}
  CIDR(listener match) -> CIDR(host match)
{code}

The cluster already knows the available addresses for each host so this is sufficient information to allow mapping to be performed on any host.

This (for example) supports mapping for both "public" and "management" interfaces.

By default no mappings would be configured and the registered host IPs would be returned.

e.g.
{code}
  dns.services.hostmapping = 172.16.55.0/24 -> 10.111.0.0/16
{code}

h4. Eucarc host mappings
A cloud configuration property will be added allowing a host match CIDR to be specified for use when mapping host IPs.

By default no mapping would be performed and registered host addresses would be returned (when not using DNS)

e.g.
{code}
  authentication.credential_download_host_match
{code}

My preference is to not implement this and instead use DNS names in eucarc when necessary.  

h4. Postgres
The postgres database service will be updated to listen only on the bind address (--bind-addr) by default. We should add another property to allow postgres to be configured specifically should this be necessary.

h4. Other services
The HTTP service and cluster services (membership, caching, etc) would not be modified.

Hi [~sjones],

Your proposal looks really good to me. Can you tell if the proposed changes will affect how DNS names for object storage buckets will be affected? For example with a cloud running on a "--bind-addr" configuration what would be output of name resolution for a bucket dns name? Will it be the IP on which the service is registered or will it be the public IP.

I ask the above question because in the ECC with the custom resolver it currently does not work as intended, perhaps the groovy script shown below is not sufficient for this task yet. But I would like to understand whether the fix to this bug would address that or not? Please let me know if you have any questions.

[~dshekhawat]

The way I understand the proposal it would be mapping the source of the request to the ip that is resolved. So if:

Registration Subnet: 10.111.1.0
Public Subnet: 10.222.1.0
VM IPs: 10.0.1.0

You could tell the CLC to respond to any lookups from 10.0.1.0 to respond with IPs that come from 10.111.1.0 and map any requests that come from 10.222.1.0 to the 10.222.1.0 IPs.

[~sjones] is that what is proposed on the DNS side? I am a bit shaky on the exact implementation as well.
[~dshekhawat], DNS host mappings would apply to user facing services, this includes the object storage gateway service.

We may need to map the IP for names such as "ns1.a-08.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com".

This is implemented as per the proposed solution except that:

* The web services listener is always available on 127.0.0.1:8773 in addition to the default address.

* Postgres listens on all IPv4 addresses by default and the setup_db.groovy configuration script has comments outlining how to customize the listener configuration if desired.

Mapping for nameservers is not implemented but likely should be. This can be handled as a separate issue once a decision is made.

Note that when the listeners for web services are changed it can take a minute for the change to be implemented.

Thanks for the explanation here.

Added a linked documentation ticket for this.

There are one or two additional cases of service addressing:

* Resolution for OSG (and "Walrus") buckets
* Resolution for nameservers ns[1-9]...

Determining when the problem is triggered is not always possible as outlined as the DNS services do not use Netty (they use sockets directly)

The DNS services should not bind 0.0.0.0 as this causes UDP responses to be sent with an incorrect IP (EUCA-8855)

The Empyrean service was not updated as part of the fix for this issue, if we want to do that I suggest we open another issue for it.

The current fix for this issue does not hard-code which addresses are returned on which interfaces. I don't think hardcoding is a good idea as it removes user (administrator) control over which address is returned.
EUCA-9249 has been opened for the nameserver A/NS record issue.

Having reviewed with [~sjones], my understanding has been rectified.  It is currently that:
# I was under the (major) false assumption that we had completed the user-facing-services part of having DNS co-located.  I should have known this as it is dependent on EUCA-8710 and friends, still on my plate.
# Given that false assumption *and* that a delegating server is the origin of requests to the internally placed DNS server, then it follows that the configuration as indicated is required. 

Is it where DNS should be for 4.0?  No, but I don't think the timing leaves a choice as prerequisite to going any further are too many other things.

The primary problem is no possibility for a sane default behaviour that works.  This being possible would be dependant upon, at least, DNS service placement being completed.  As such, I am still reluctant to leave this as it is, but am resigned to it because of the timing.

@sjones, to your other comments:

* Correct:  I neglected virtual buckets and NS records in my listing.

* The DNS server responding incorrectly when listening on the any-address is a bug that should be fixed. Especially, as it is incorrect behaviour that is inturn impacting the design.

* To be sure, the Empyrean Service issue is for when DNS is not enabled, and is here: EUCA-9250.

* I completely agree with enabling the configuration of DNS behaviour, but it should not come at the cost of a sane default behaviour.  Granted that kind of behaviour is not currently possible when more than one mutually unroutable network can be the source of requests.
@sjones, I too wonder why DNS is not based on netty.
EUCA-9252 now reflects the netty & 0.0.0.0 bind address issue.
When not using DNS, there may be cases where user facing IPs are propagated to internal components leading to failures (e.g. the URL(s) for/in an import instance image import manifest)

No issues found due to this topology. Used --bind-addr and the appropriate listener match properties, host mapping, and credential mapping properties:

{noformat}
 "bootstrap.webservices.use_dns_delegation": "true",
         "bootstrap.webservices.use_instance_dns": "true",
         "system.dns.dnsdomain": "g-12-03.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com",
         "dns.services.hostmapping": "10.111.0.0/16->10.111.0.0/16",
         "dns.dns_listener_address_match": "0.0.0.0/0",
         "authentication.credential_download_host_match": "10.111.0.0/16"
{noformat}
